channel.title: Command Rankings, and how to use them properly
channel.description:
[center][size=14pt][i][b]Command Rankings, and how to use them properly.[/b][/i][/size] As you see in most servers there are signs and symbols when coding, for example when adding in commands.
[code]<=[/code]
This sign means equal to, or lesser than and usually a number comes after it to show you the highest rank to be able to use it, and anything lesser than that rank will be capable to use it as well.
[code]>=[/code]
This sign means equal to, or greater than and as I stated before a number usually comes after it. Though this time it shows you the highest rank, and any other greater ranks that are capable of using the following command.
[code]==[/code]
This sign solidifies the rank, nothing greater, or lesser than the specific rank issued will be capable of using this command.
[code]& and &&[/code]
For boolean arguments, the single ampersand constitutes the (unconditional) "logical AND" operator while the double ampersand ("&&") is the "conditional logical AND" operator. That is to say that the single ampersand always evaluates both arguments whereas the double ampersand will only evaluate the second argument if the first argument is true.
[code]||[/code]
("||") is the "conditional logical OR" operator. These operators exhibit ways only if needed so. It is as well pretty much related to the ("&&").
[code]!=[/code] This sign here pretty much means not equal to.
[b][size=14pt][i]Here is an example.[/i][/size][/b]
[code]if (playerCommand.startsWith("spawn")&&c.playerRights == 3) {[/code]
This solidifies only the person who has the player rights 3 able to use the command. Nothing lesser than, or greater than is capable of using the command.
[code]if (playerCommand.startsWith("spawn")&&c.playerRights >= 3) {[/code]
This is now changed so that anything equal to owner rights, or greater than owner rights now capable of using the command.
[code]if (playerCommand.startsWith("spawn")&&c.playerRights <= 3) {[/code]
This is now changed so that anything equal to owner rights, or lesser than owner rights now capable of using the command.
[u]________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________[/u]
[b][size=14pt][i]Setting a command for a specific player.[/i][/size][/b] First of all let me explain how to set a command for a specific player.
[code]equalsIgnoreCase[/code]
Determines whether two String objects contain the same data, ignoring the case of the letters in the String. Meaning whether it contains capitals or not, it will still grab the correct whole texts within the brackets.
[code]playerName[/code]
playerName obviously determines the players username he whom created his account with.
[code]("")[/code]
This is where you place the players username or whole text.
[i][b][size=14pt]Here is an example.[/size][/b][/i]
[code]if (playerCommand.startsWith("npc") && c.playerName.equalsIgnoreCase("Encryption")) {[/code]
As you see I have set the command to myself, showing both the command and whom it was set to. [u]________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________[/u]
It's very simple but most do not know the following of which I've stated. I'm also not entirely aware if this is the correct section for posting my little lesson. This tutorial can go on forever that's why I made it related to player commands in order for you to get an idea of it when you come across it while developing your servers. Players are more than welcome to add on, or ask for anything else related to these case. Thank-you.[/center]

item.title: Command Rankings, and how to use them properly
item.dc:creator: @Encryption Encryption
item.description:
@Encryption wrote:

[quote=“arham 4, post:16, topic:534589”][quote author=Clawz fury link=topic=653385.msg4380541#msg4380541 date=1383369388]

This is why I love learning everything I know from complete RSPS.

and this is also why you’re going to have a tough ass time learning concurrency and other more advanced stuff

have fun
[/quote]

I feel dumb now.[/quote]

Your not dumb. <3

Read full topic

item.source: Command Rankings, and how to use them properly

item.title: Command Rankings, and how to use them properly
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:11, topic:534589”][quote author=arham 4 link=topic=653385.msg4378917#msg4378917 date=1382915760]

Is this necessary? If you don’t know this, then you don’t understand the basic concepts of programming and shouldn’t be developing a program (in this case, a private server).

You can literally find a better explanation for this and more on like the first page of the java tutorial on the oracle website.

Try explaining something that a lot of people have trouble understanding, even with java tutorials available (object orientated programming concepts, concurrency, …).

No, docs are all confusing. ALL of it. Even the freaking HelloWorld.

This is why I love learning everything I know from complete RSPS. Tried the docs out, ain’t touching that thing ever again.

(Though I love Apache (the makers of the network MINA, NOT the user Apache)'s doc on their networking. Nice, to the point, and very well explained)

[hr]

I like this.
[/quote]

This is the dumbest thing I have ever read.

The reason docs are hard for you to understand is because you aren’t grasping the terminology that is used–Google unfamiliar words. Never skim docs, the large walls of text is there for a reason, each doc in my opinion explains things nicely, other than a few that don’t provide practical usages or examples, that’s when I resort to Google.[/quote]sorry cutie but going to have to agree with Ryley on this one. <3

Docs are there for guidance you are still meant to do your own research as needed.

Read full topic
